saml.name: Javascript Mapper
saml.helpText: Evaluates a JavaScript function to produce an attribute value based on context information.

properties.name: Script
properties.label: Script
properties.helpText:
Script to compute the attribute value. 
 Available variables: 
 'user' - the current user.
 'realm' - the current realm.
 'clientSession' - the current clientSession.
 'userSession' - the current userSession.
 'keycloakSession' - the current keycloakSession.

To use: the last statement is the value returned to Java.
The result will be tested if it can be iterated upon (e.g. an array or a collection).
 - If it is not, toString() will be called on the object to get the value of the attribute
 - If it is, toString() will be called on all elements to return multiple attribute values.
properties.defaultValue:
/**
 * Available variables: 
 * user - the current user
 * realm - the current realm
 * clientSession - the current clientSession
 * userSession - the current userSession
 * keycloakSession - the current keycloakSession
 */

saml.helpText: Keycloak SAML adapter configuration file you must edit. Put this in WEB-INF directory of your WAR.
CLI script you must edit and apply to your client app server. This type of configuration is useful when you can't or don't want to crack open your WAR file.
SAML SP Metadata EntityDescriptor or rather SPSSODescriptor. This is an XML file.
Keycloak SAML adapter JBoss subsystem xml you must edit. Put this into <subsystem xmlns="urn:jboss:domain:keycloak-saml:1.2"> element of your standalone.xml file.

This is a zip file.  It contains a SAML SP descriptor, SAML IDP descriptor,  private key pem, and certificate pem that you will use to configure mod_auth_mellon for Apache.  You'll use these files when crafting the main Apache configuration file.  See mod_auth_mellon website for more details.

docker-v2.helpText: Configures environment variable overrides, typically used with a docker-compose.yaml configuration for a docker registry
Provides a registry configuration file snippet for use with this client
Produces a zip file that can be used to stand up a development registry on localhost

openid-connect.helpText: CLI script you must edit and apply to your client app server. This type of configuration is useful when you can't or don't want to crack open your WAR file.
XML snippet you must edit and add to the Keycloak OIDC subsystem on your client app server.  This type of configuration is useful when you can't or don't want to crack open your WAR file.

keycloak.json file used by the Keycloak OIDC client adapter to configure clients.  This must be saved to a keycloak.json file and put in your WEB-INF directory of your WAR file.  You may also want to tweak this file after you download it.

org.keycloak.authentication.FormAction.helpText: Validates that password matches password confirmation field.  It also will store password in user's credential store.
Validates email, first name, and last name attributes and stores them in user data.
Adds Google Recaptcha button.  Recaptchas verify that the entity that is registering is a human.  This can only be used on the internet and must be configured after you add it.

properties.name: site.key
properties.label: Recaptcha Site Key
properties.helpText: Google Recaptcha Site Key

properties.name: secret
properties.label: Recaptcha Secret
properties.helpText: Google Recaptcha Secret

properties.name: useRecaptchaNet
properties.label: use recaptcha.net
properties.helpText: Use recaptcha.net? (or else google.com)

org.keycloak.authentication.FormAction.helpText: This action must always be first! Validates the username of the user in validation phase.  In success phase, this will create the user in the database.

org.keycloak.authentication.Authenticato.helpText: Authenticator will always successfully authenticate. Useful for example in the conditional flows to be used after satisfying the previous conditions
Validates a OTP on a separate OTP form. Only shown if required based on the configured conditions.

properties.name: otpControlAttribute
properties.label: OTP control User Attribute
properties.helpText: The name of the user attribute to explicitly control OTP auth. If attribute value is 'force' then OTP is always required. If value is 'skip' the OTP auth is skipped. Otherwise this check is ignored.

properties.name: skipOtpRole
properties.label: Skip OTP for Role
properties.helpText: OTP is always skipped if user has the given Role.

properties.name: forceOtpRole
properties.label: Force OTP for Role
properties.helpText: OTP is always required if user has the given Role.

properties.name: noOtpRequiredForHeaderPattern
properties.label: Skip OTP for Header
properties.helpText: OTP is skipped if a HTTP request header does matches the given pattern.Can be used to specify trusted networks via: X-Forwarded-Host: (1.2.3.4|1.2.3.5).In this case requests from 1.2.3.4 and 1.2.3.5 come from a trusted source.

properties.name: forceOtpForHeaderPattern
properties.label: Force OTP for Header
properties.helpText: OTP required if a HTTP request header matches the given pattern.

properties.name: defaultOtpOutcome
properties.label: Fallback OTP handling
properties.helpText: What to do in case of every check abstains. Defaults to force OTP authentication.

org.keycloak.authentication.Authenticato.helpText: Validates the SSO cookie set by the auth server.
Validates a OTP on a separate OTP form.
Validates a password from login form.
Initiates the SPNEGO protocol.  Most often used with Kerberos.
Selects a user from his username.
Validates a username and password from login form.
Validates username and password from X509 client certificate received as a part of mutual SSL handshake.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.mapping-source-selection
properties.label: User Identity Source
properties.helpText: Choose how to extract user identity from X509 certificate or the certificate fields. For example, SubjectDN will match the custom regular expression specified below to the value of certificate's SubjectDN field.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.canonical-dn-enabled
properties.label: Canonical DN representation enabled
properties.helpText: Use the canonical format to determine the distinguished name. This option is relevant for authenticators using a distinguished name.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.serialnumber-hex-enabled
properties.label: Enable Serial Number hexadecimal representation
properties.helpText: Use the hex representation of the serial number. This option is relevant for authenticators using serial number.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.regular-expression
properties.label: A regular expression to extract user identity
properties.helpText: The regular expression to extract a user identity. The expression must contain a single group. For example, 'uniqueId=(.*?)(?:,|$)' will match 'uniqueId=somebody@company.org, CN=somebody' and give somebody@company.org

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.mapper-selection
properties.label: User mapping method
properties.helpText: Choose how to map extracted user identities to users

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.mapper-selection.user-attribute-name
properties.label: A name of user attribute
properties.helpText: A name of user attribute to map the extracted user identity to existing user. The name must be a valid, existing user attribute if User Mapping Method is set to Custom Attribute Mapper. Multiple values are relevant when attribute mapping is related to multiple values, e.g. 'Certificate Serial Number and IssuerDN'

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.timestamp-validation-enabled
properties.label: Check certificate validity
properties.helpText: Will verify that the certificate has not expired yet and is already valid by checking the attributes 'notBefore' and 'notAfter'.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.crl-checking-enabled
properties.label: CRL Checking Enabled
properties.helpText: Enable Certificate Revocation Checking using CRL

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.crldp-checking-enabled
properties.label: Enable CRL Distribution Point to check certificate revocation status
properties.helpText: CRL Distribution Point is a starting point for CRL. If this is ON, then CRL checking will be done based on the CRL distribution points included in the checked certificates. CDP is optional, but most PKI authorities include CDP in their certificates.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.crl-relative-path
properties.label: CRL Path
properties.helpText: Applied just if CRL checking is ON and CRL Distribution point is OFF. It contains the URL (typically 'http' or 'ldap') where the CRL is available. Alternatively it can contain the path to a CRL file that contains a list of revoked certificates. Paths are assumed to be relative to $jboss.server.config.dir. Multiple CRLs can be included, however it can affect performance as the certificate will be checked against all listed CRLs.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.ocsp-checking-enabled
properties.label: OCSP Checking Enabled
properties.helpText: Enable Certificate Revocation Checking using OCSP

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.ocsp-fail-open
properties.label: OCSP Fail-Open Behavior
properties.helpText: Whether to allow or deny authentication for client certificates that have missing/invalid/inconclusive OCSP endpoints. By default a successful OCSP response is required.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.ocsp-responder-uri
properties.label: OCSP Responder Uri
properties.helpText: Clients use OCSP Responder Uri to check certificate revocation status.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.ocsp-responder-certificate
properties.label: OCSP Responder Certificate
properties.helpText: Optional certificate used by the responder to sign the responses. The certificate should be in PEM format without BEGIN and END tags. It is only used if the OCSP Responder URI is set. By default, the certificate of the OCSP responder is that of the issuer of the certificate being validated or one with the OCSPSigning extension and also issued by the same CA. This option identifies the certificate of the OCSP responder when the defaults do not apply.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.keyusage
properties.label: Validate Key Usage
properties.helpText: Validates that the purpose of the key contained in the certificate (encipherment, signature, etc.) matches its intended purpose. Leaving the field blank will disable Key Usage validation. For example, 'digitalSignature, keyEncipherment' will check if the digitalSignature and keyEncipherment bits (bit 0 and bit 2 respectively) are set in certificate's X509 Key Usage extension. See RFC 5280 for a detailed definition of X509 Key Usage extension.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.extendedkeyusage
properties.label: Validate Extended Key Usage
properties.helpText: Validates the extended purposes of the certificate's key using certificate's Extended Key Usage extension. Leaving the field blank will disable Extended Key Usage validation. See RFC 5280 for a detailed definition of X509 Extended Key Usage extension.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.confirmation-page-disallowed
properties.label: Bypass identity confirmation
properties.helpText: By default, the users are prompted to confirm their identity extracted from X509 client certificate. The identity confirmation prompt is skipped if the option is switched on.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.revalidate-certificate-enabled
properties.label: Revalidate Client Certificate
properties.helpText: Forces revalidation of the client certificate according to the certificates defined in the truststore. This is useful when behind a non-validating proxy or when the number of allowed certificate chains would be too large for mutual SSL negotiation.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.certificate-policy
properties.label: Validate Certificate Policy
properties.helpText: Validates the certificate policies of the certificate's key using certificate's Policy extension. Leaving the field blank will disable Certificate Policies validation. Multiple policies should be separated using a comma. See RFC 5280 for a detailed definition of X509 Certificate Policy extension.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.certificate-policy-mode
properties.label: Certificate Policy Validation Mode
properties.helpText: If Certificate Policy validation is specified, indicates whether it should match all or at least one of the specified policies.

org.keycloak.authentication.Authenticato.helpText: Challenge-response authentication using HTTP BASIC scheme.

Challenge-response authentication using HTTP BASIC scheme.  Password param should contain a combination of password + otp. Realm's OTP policy is used to determine how to parse this. This SHOULD NOT BE USED in conjection with regular basic auth provider.

Flow is executed only if the configured LOA or a higher one has been requested but not yet satisfied. After the flow is successfully finished, the LOA in the session will be updated to value prescribed by this condition.

properties.name: loa-condition-level
properties.label: loa-condition-level
properties.helpText: loa-condition-level.tooltip

properties.name: loa-store-in-user-session
properties.label: loa-store-in-user-session
properties.helpText: loa-store-in-user-session.tooltip

org.keycloak.authentication.Authenticato.helpText: Executes the current flow only if authenticators are configured
Flow is executed only if user has the given role.

properties.name: condUserRole
properties.label: User role
properties.helpText: Role the user should have to execute this flow. Click 'Select Role' button to browse roles, or just type it in the textbox. To reference a client role the syntax is clientname.clientrole, i.e. myclient.myrole

properties.name: negate
properties.label: Negate output
properties.helpText: Apply a NOT to the check result. When this is true, then the condition will evaluate to true just if user does NOT have the specified role. When this is false, the condition will evaluate to true just if user has the specified role

org.keycloak.authentication.Authenticato.helpText: Proprietary challenge protocol for CLI clients that queries for username password
Access will be always denied. Useful for example in the conditional flows to be used after satisfying the previous conditions

properties.name: denyErrorMessage
properties.label: Error message
properties.helpText: Error message which will be shown to the user. You can directly define particular message or property, which will be used for mapping the error message f.e `deny-access-role1`. If the field is blank, default property 'access-denied' is used.

org.keycloak.authentication.Authenticato.helpText: Validates username and password from X509 client certificate received as a part of mutual SSL handshake.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.mapping-source-selection
properties.label: User Identity Source
properties.helpText: Choose how to extract user identity from X509 certificate or the certificate fields. For example, SubjectDN will match the custom regular expression specified below to the value of certificate's SubjectDN field.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.canonical-dn-enabled
properties.label: Canonical DN representation enabled
properties.helpText: Use the canonical format to determine the distinguished name. This option is relevant for authenticators using a distinguished name.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.serialnumber-hex-enabled
properties.label: Enable Serial Number hexadecimal representation
properties.helpText: Use the hex representation of the serial number. This option is relevant for authenticators using serial number.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.regular-expression
properties.label: A regular expression to extract user identity
properties.helpText: The regular expression to extract a user identity. The expression must contain a single group. For example, 'uniqueId=(.*?)(?:,|$)' will match 'uniqueId=somebody@company.org, CN=somebody' and give somebody@company.org

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.mapper-selection
properties.label: User mapping method
properties.helpText: Choose how to map extracted user identities to users

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.mapper-selection.user-attribute-name
properties.label: A name of user attribute
properties.helpText: A name of user attribute to map the extracted user identity to existing user. The name must be a valid, existing user attribute if User Mapping Method is set to Custom Attribute Mapper. Multiple values are relevant when attribute mapping is related to multiple values, e.g. 'Certificate Serial Number and IssuerDN'

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.timestamp-validation-enabled
properties.label: Check certificate validity
properties.helpText: Will verify that the certificate has not expired yet and is already valid by checking the attributes 'notBefore' and 'notAfter'.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.crl-checking-enabled
properties.label: CRL Checking Enabled
properties.helpText: Enable Certificate Revocation Checking using CRL

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.crldp-checking-enabled
properties.label: Enable CRL Distribution Point to check certificate revocation status
properties.helpText: CRL Distribution Point is a starting point for CRL. If this is ON, then CRL checking will be done based on the CRL distribution points included in the checked certificates. CDP is optional, but most PKI authorities include CDP in their certificates.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.crl-relative-path
properties.label: CRL Path
properties.helpText: Applied just if CRL checking is ON and CRL Distribution point is OFF. It contains the URL (typically 'http' or 'ldap') where the CRL is available. Alternatively it can contain the path to a CRL file that contains a list of revoked certificates. Paths are assumed to be relative to $jboss.server.config.dir. Multiple CRLs can be included, however it can affect performance as the certificate will be checked against all listed CRLs.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.ocsp-checking-enabled
properties.label: OCSP Checking Enabled
properties.helpText: Enable Certificate Revocation Checking using OCSP

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.ocsp-fail-open
properties.label: OCSP Fail-Open Behavior
properties.helpText: Whether to allow or deny authentication for client certificates that have missing/invalid/inconclusive OCSP endpoints. By default a successful OCSP response is required.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.ocsp-responder-uri
properties.label: OCSP Responder Uri
properties.helpText: Clients use OCSP Responder Uri to check certificate revocation status.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.ocsp-responder-certificate
properties.label: OCSP Responder Certificate
properties.helpText: Optional certificate used by the responder to sign the responses. The certificate should be in PEM format without BEGIN and END tags. It is only used if the OCSP Responder URI is set. By default, the certificate of the OCSP responder is that of the issuer of the certificate being validated or one with the OCSPSigning extension and also issued by the same CA. This option identifies the certificate of the OCSP responder when the defaults do not apply.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.keyusage
properties.label: Validate Key Usage
properties.helpText: Validates that the purpose of the key contained in the certificate (encipherment, signature, etc.) matches its intended purpose. Leaving the field blank will disable Key Usage validation. For example, 'digitalSignature, keyEncipherment' will check if the digitalSignature and keyEncipherment bits (bit 0 and bit 2 respectively) are set in certificate's X509 Key Usage extension. See RFC 5280 for a detailed definition of X509 Key Usage extension.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.extendedkeyusage
properties.label: Validate Extended Key Usage
properties.helpText: Validates the extended purposes of the certificate's key using certificate's Extended Key Usage extension. Leaving the field blank will disable Extended Key Usage validation. See RFC 5280 for a detailed definition of X509 Extended Key Usage extension.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.confirmation-page-disallowed
properties.label: Bypass identity confirmation
properties.helpText: By default, the users are prompted to confirm their identity extracted from X509 client certificate. The identity confirmation prompt is skipped if the option is switched on.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.revalidate-certificate-enabled
properties.label: Revalidate Client Certificate
properties.helpText: Forces revalidation of the client certificate according to the certificates defined in the truststore. This is useful when behind a non-validating proxy or when the number of allowed certificate chains would be too large for mutual SSL negotiation.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.certificate-policy
properties.label: Validate Certificate Policy
properties.helpText: Validates the certificate policies of the certificate's key using certificate's Policy extension. Leaving the field blank will disable Certificate Policies validation. Multiple policies should be separated using a comma. See RFC 5280 for a detailed definition of X509 Certificate Policy extension.

properties.name: x509-cert-auth.certificate-policy-mode
properties.label: Certificate Policy Validation Mode
properties.helpText: If Certificate Policy validation is specified, indicates whether it should match all or at least one of the specified policies.

org.keycloak.authentication.Authenticato.helpText: Validates the one time password supplied as a 'totp' form parameter in direct grant request
Validates the password supplied as a 'password' form parameter in direct grant request
Validates the username supplied as a 'username' form parameter in direct grant request
Uses HTTP Basic authentication to validate docker users, returning a docker error token on auth failure
Validates username and password from Authorization HTTP header
Redirects to default Identity Provider or Identity Provider specified with kc_idp_hint query parameter

properties.name: defaultProvider
properties.label: Default Identity Provider
properties.helpText: To automatically redirect to an identity provider set to the alias of the identity provider

org.keycloak.authentication.Authenticato.helpText: Automatically set existing user to authentication context without any verification
Show the form where user confirms if he wants to link identity provider with existing account or rather edit user profile data retrieved from identity provider to avoid conflict
Detect if there is existing Keycloak account with same email like identity provider. If no, create new user

properties.name: require.password.update.after.registration
properties.label: Require Password Update After Registration
properties.helpText: If this option is true and new user is successfully imported from Identity Provider to Keycloak (there is no duplicated email or username detected in Keycloak DB), then this user is required to update his password

org.keycloak.authentication.Authenticato.helpText: Detect if there is an existing Keycloak account with same email like identity provider. If no, throw an error.
Email verification of existing Keycloak user, that wants to link his user account with identity provider
User reviews and updates profile data retrieved from Identity Provider in the displayed form

properties.name: update.profile.on.first.login
properties.label: {{:: 'update-profile-on-first-login' | translate}}
properties.helpText: Define conditions under which a user has to review and update his profile after first-time login. Value 'On' means that page for reviewing profile will be displayed and user can review and update his profile. Value 'off' means that page won't be displayed. Value 'missing' means that page is displayed just when some required attribute is missing (wasn't downloaded from identity provider). Value 'missing' is the default one. WARN: In case that user clicks 'Review profile info' on link duplications page, the update page will be always displayed. You would need to disable this authenticator to never display the page.

org.keycloak.authentication.Authenticato.helpText: Validates a password from login form. Username may be already known from identity provider authentication
Perform a 302 redirect to get user agent's current URI on authenticate path with an auth_session_id query parameter.  This is for client's that do not support cookies.
Send email to user and wait for response.
Choose a user to reset credentials for
Sets the Configure OTP required action.
Sets the Update Password required action if execution is REQUIRED.  Will also set it if execution is OPTIONAL and the password is currently configured for it.
Configures how many concurrent sessions a single user is allowed to create for this realm and/or client

properties.name: userRealmLimit
properties.label: Maximum concurrent sessions for each user within this realm.
properties.helpText: Provide a zero or negative value to disable this limit.

properties.name: userClientLimit
properties.label: Maximum concurrent sessions for each user per keycloak client.
properties.helpText: Provide a zero or negative value to disable this limit. In case a limit for the realm is enabled, specify this value below the total realm limit.

properties.name: behavior
properties.label: Behavior when user session limit is exceeded

properties.name: errorMessage
properties.label: Optional custom error message
properties.helpText: If left empty a default error message is shown

org.keycloak.authentication.Authenticato.helpText: Authenticator for WebAuthn. Usually used for WebAuthn two-factor authentication
Authenticator for Passwordless WebAuthn authentication

properties.name: kerberosRealm
properties.label: kerberos-realm
properties.helpText: kerberos-realm.tooltip

properties.name: serverPrincipal
properties.label: server-principal
properties.helpText: server-principal.tooltip

properties.name: keyTab
properties.label: keytab
properties.helpText: keytab.tooltip

properties.name: debug
properties.label: debug
properties.helpText: debug.tooltip

properties.name: allowPasswordAuthentication
properties.label: allow-password-authentication
properties.helpText: allow-password-authentication.tooltip

properties.name: editMode
properties.label: edit-mode
properties.helpText: edit-mode.tooltip

properties.name: updateProfileFirstLogin
properties.label: update-profile-first-login
properties.helpText: update-profile-first-login.tooltip

org.keycloak.storage.ldap.mappers.LDAPSt.helpText: Used to map single attribute which contains a certificate from LDAP user to attribute of UserModel in Keycloak DB

properties.name: user.model.attribute
properties.label: User Model Attribute
properties.helpText: Name of the UserModel property or attribute you want to map the LDAP attribute into. For example 'firstName', 'lastName, 'email', 'street' etc.

properties.name: ldap.attribute
properties.label: LDAP Attribute
properties.helpText: Name of mapped attribute on LDAP object. For example 'cn', 'sn, 'mail', 'street' etc.

properties.name: read.only
properties.label: Read Only
properties.helpText: Read-only attribute is imported from LDAP to UserModel, but it's not saved back to LDAP when user is updated in Keycloak.

properties.name: always.read.value.from.ldap
properties.label: Always Read Value From LDAP
properties.helpText: If on, then during reading of the LDAP attribute value will always used instead of the value from Keycloak DB

properties.name: is.mandatory.in.ldap
properties.label: Is Mandatory In LDAP
properties.helpText: If true, attribute is mandatory in LDAP. Hence if there is no value in Keycloak DB, the default or empty value will be set to be propagated to LDAP

properties.name: attribute.default.value
properties.label: Attribute default value
properties.helpText: If there is no value in Keycloak DB and attribute is mandatory in LDAP, this value will be propagated to LDAP

properties.name: is.binary.attribute
properties.label: Is Binary Attribute
properties.helpText: Should be true for binary LDAP attributes

properties.name: is.der.formatted
properties.label: DER Formatted
properties.helpText: Activate this if the certificate is DER formatted in LDAP and not PEM formatted.

org.keycloak.storage.ldap.mappers.LDAPSt.helpText: Used to map full-name of user from single attribute in LDAP (usually 'cn' attribute) to firstName and lastName attributes of UserModel in Keycloak DB

properties.name: ldap.full.name.attribute
properties.label: LDAP Full Name Attribute
properties.helpText: Name of LDAP attribute, which contains fullName of user. Usually it will be 'cn'

properties.name: read.only
properties.label: Read Only
properties.helpText: For Read-only is data imported from LDAP to Keycloak DB, but it's not saved back to LDAP when user is updated in Keycloak.

properties.name: write.only
properties.label: Write Only
properties.helpText: For Write-only is data propagated to LDAP when user is created or updated in Keycloak. But this mapper is not used to propagate data from LDAP back into Keycloak. This setting is useful if you configured separate firstName and lastName attribute mappers and you want to use those to read attribute from LDAP into Keycloak

org.keycloak.storage.ldap.mappers.LDAPSt.helpText: Used to map group mappings of groups from some LDAP DN to Keycloak group mappings

properties.name: groups.dn
properties.label: LDAP Groups DN
properties.helpText: LDAP DN where are groups of this tree saved. For example 'ou=groups,dc=example,dc=org'

properties.name: group.name.ldap.attribute
properties.label: Group Name LDAP Attribute
properties.helpText: Name of LDAP attribute, which is used in group objects for name and RDN of group. Usually it will be 'cn' . In this case typical group/role object may have DN like 'cn=Group1,ou=groups,dc=example,dc=org'

properties.name: group.object.classes
properties.label: Group Object Classes
properties.helpText: Object class (or classes) of the group object. It's divided by comma if more classes needed. In typical LDAP deployment it could be 'groupOfNames' . In Active Directory it's usually 'group'

properties.name: preserve.group.inheritance
properties.label: Preserve Group Inheritance
properties.helpText: Flag whether group inheritance from LDAP should be propagated to Keycloak. If false, then all LDAP groups will be mapped as flat top-level groups in Keycloak. Otherwise group inheritance is preserved into Keycloak, but the group sync might fail if LDAP structure contains recursions or multiple parent groups per child groups

properties.name: ignore.missing.groups
properties.label: Ignore Missing Groups
properties.helpText: Ignore missing groups in the group hierarchy

properties.name: membership.ldap.attribute
properties.label: Membership LDAP Attribute
properties.helpText: Name of LDAP attribute on group, which is used for membership mappings. Usually it will be 'member' .However when 'Membership Attribute Type' is 'UID' then 'Membership LDAP Attribute' could be typically 'memberUid' .

properties.name: membership.attribute.type
properties.label: Membership Attribute Type
properties.helpText: DN means that LDAP group has it's members declared in form of their full DN. For example 'member: uid=john,ou=users,dc=example,dc=com' . UID means that LDAP group has it's members declared in form of pure user uids. For example 'memberUid: john' .

properties.name: membership.user.ldap.attribute
properties.label: Membership User LDAP Attribute
properties.helpText: Used just if Membership Attribute Type is UID. It is name of LDAP attribute on user, which is used for membership mappings. Usually it will be 'uid' . For example if value of 'Membership User LDAP Attribute' is 'uid' and  LDAP group has  'memberUid: john', then it is expected that particular LDAP user will have attribute 'uid: john' .

properties.name: groups.ldap.filter
properties.label: LDAP Filter
properties.helpText: LDAP Filter adds additional custom filter to the whole query for retrieve LDAP groups. Leave this empty if no additional filtering is needed and you want to retrieve all groups from LDAP. Otherwise make sure that filter starts with '(' and ends with ')'

properties.name: mode
properties.label: Mode
properties.helpText: LDAP_ONLY means that all group mappings of users are retrieved from LDAP and saved into LDAP. READ_ONLY is Read-only LDAP mode where group mappings are retrieved from both LDAP and DB and merged together. New group joins are not saved to LDAP but to DB. IMPORT is Read-only LDAP mode where group mappings are retrieved from LDAP just at the time when user is imported from LDAP and then they are saved to local keycloak DB.

properties.name: user.roles.retrieve.strategy
properties.label: User Groups Retrieve Strategy
properties.helpText: Specify how to retrieve groups of user. LOAD_GROUPS_BY_MEMBER_ATTRIBUTE means that roles of user will be retrieved by sending LDAP query to retrieve all groups where 'member' is our user. GET_GROUPS_FROM_USER_MEMBEROF_ATTRIBUTE means that groups of user will be retrieved from 'memberOf' attribute of our user. Or from the other attribute specified by 'Member-Of LDAP Attribute' .

properties.name: memberof.ldap.attribute
properties.label: Member-Of LDAP Attribute
properties.helpText: Used just when 'User Roles Retrieve Strategy' is GET_GROUPS_FROM_USER_MEMBEROF_ATTRIBUTE . It specifies the name of the LDAP attribute on the LDAP user, which contains the groups, which the user is member of. Usually it will be 'memberOf' and that's also the default value.

properties.name: mapped.group.attributes
properties.label: Mapped Group Attributes
properties.helpText: List of names of attributes divided by comma. This points to the list of attributes on LDAP group, which will be mapped as attributes of Group in Keycloak. Leave this empty if no additional group attributes are required to be mapped in Keycloak.

properties.name: drop.non.existing.groups.during.sync
properties.label: Drop non-existing groups during sync
properties.helpText: If this flag is true, then during sync of groups from LDAP to Keycloak, we will keep just those Keycloak groups, which still exists in LDAP. Rest will be deleted

properties.name: groups.path
properties.label: Groups Path
properties.helpText: Keycloak group path the LDAP groups are added to. For example if value '/Applications/App1' is used, then LDAP groups will be available in Keycloak under group 'App1', which is child of top level group 'Applications'. The default value is '/' so LDAP groups will be mapped to the Keycloak groups at the top level. The configured group path must already exists in the Keycloak when creating this mapper.

org.keycloak.storage.ldap.mappers.LDAPSt.helpText: This mapper will hardcode any model user attribute and some property (like emailVerified or enabled) when importing user from ldap.

properties.name: user.model.attribute
properties.label: User Model Attribute Name
properties.helpText: Name of the model attribute, which will be added when importing user from ldap

properties.name: attribute.value
properties.label: Attribute Value
properties.helpText: Value of the model attribute, which will be added when importing user from ldap.

org.keycloak.storage.ldap.mappers.LDAPSt.helpText: This mapper is supported just if syncRegistrations is enabled. When new user is registered in Keycloak, he will be written to the LDAP with the hardcoded value of some specified attribute.

properties.name: ldap.attribute.name
properties.label: LDAP Attribute Name
properties.helpText: Name of the LDAP attribute, which will be added to the new user during registration

properties.name: ldap.attribute.value
properties.label: LDAP Attribute Value
properties.helpText: Value of the LDAP attribute, which will be added to the new user during registration. You can either hardcode any value like 'foo' but you can also use some special tokens. Only supported token right now is '${RANDOM}' , which will be replaced with some randomly generated String.

org.keycloak.storage.ldap.mappers.LDAPSt.helpText: When user is imported from LDAP, he will be automatically added into this configured group.

properties.name: group
properties.label: Group
properties.helpText: Group to add the user in. Fill the full path of the group including path. For example '/root-group/child-group'

org.keycloak.storage.ldap.mappers.LDAPSt.helpText: When user is imported from LDAP, he will be automatically added into this configured role.

properties.name: role
properties.label: Role
properties.helpText: Role to grant to user.  Click 'Select Role' button to browse roles, or just type it in the textbox.  To reference a client role the syntax is clientname.clientrole, i.e. myclient.myrole

org.keycloak.storage.ldap.mappers.LDAPSt.helpText: Mapper specific to MSAD LDS. It's able to integrate the MSAD LDS user account state into Keycloak account state (account enabled, password is expired etc). It's using msDS-UserAccountDisabled and pwdLastSet MSAD attributes for that. For example if pwdLastSet is 0, the Keycloak user is required to update password, if msDS-UserAccountDisabled is 'TRUE' the Keycloak user is disabled as well etc. Mapper is also able to handle exception code from LDAP user authentication.

Mapper specific to MSAD. It's able to integrate the MSAD user account state into Keycloak account state (account enabled, password is expired etc). It's using userAccountControl and pwdLastSet MSAD attributes for that. For example if pwdLastSet is 0, the Keycloak user is required to update password, if userAccountControl is 514 (disabled account) the Keycloak user is disabled as well etc. Mapper is also able to handle exception code from LDAP user authentication.

properties.name: ldap.password.policy.hints.enabled
properties.label: Password Policy Hints Enabled
properties.helpText: Applicable just for writable MSAD. If on, then updating password of MSAD user will use LDAP_SERVER_POLICY_HINTS_OID extension, which means that advanced MSAD password policies like 'password history' or 'minimal password age' will be applied. This extension works just for MSAD 2008 R2 or newer.

org.keycloak.storage.ldap.mappers.LDAPSt.helpText: Used to map role mappings of roles from some LDAP DN to Keycloak role mappings of either realm roles or client roles of particular client

properties.name: roles.dn
properties.label: LDAP Roles DN
properties.helpText: LDAP DN where are roles of this tree saved. For example 'ou=finance,dc=example,dc=org'

properties.name: role.name.ldap.attribute
properties.label: Role Name LDAP Attribute
properties.helpText: Name of LDAP attribute, which is used in role objects for name and RDN of role. Usually it will be 'cn' . In this case typical group/role object may have DN like 'cn=role1,ou=finance,dc=example,dc=org'

properties.name: role.object.classes
properties.label: Role Object Classes
properties.helpText: Object class (or classes) of the role object. It's divided by comma if more classes needed. In typical LDAP deployment it could be 'groupOfNames' . In Active Directory it's usually 'group'

properties.name: membership.ldap.attribute
properties.label: Membership LDAP Attribute
properties.helpText: Name of LDAP attribute on role, which is used for membership mappings. Usually it will be 'member' .However when 'Membership Attribute Type' is 'UID' then 'Membership LDAP Attribute' could be typically 'memberUid' .

properties.name: membership.attribute.type
properties.label: Membership Attribute Type
properties.helpText: DN means that LDAP role has it's members declared in form of their full DN. For example 'member: uid=john,ou=users,dc=example,dc=com' . UID means that LDAP role has it's members declared in form of pure user uids. For example 'memberUid: john' .

properties.name: membership.user.ldap.attribute
properties.label: Membership User LDAP Attribute
properties.helpText: Used just if Membership Attribute Type is UID. It is name of LDAP attribute on user, which is used for membership mappings. Usually it will be 'uid' . For example if value of 'Membership User LDAP Attribute' is 'uid' and  LDAP group has  'memberUid: john', then it is expected that particular LDAP user will have attribute 'uid: john' .

properties.name: roles.ldap.filter
properties.label: LDAP Filter
properties.helpText: LDAP Filter adds additional custom filter to the whole query for retrieve LDAP roles. Leave this empty if no additional filtering is needed and you want to retrieve all roles from LDAP. Otherwise make sure that filter starts with '(' and ends with ')'

properties.name: mode
properties.label: Mode
properties.helpText: LDAP_ONLY means that all role mappings are retrieved from LDAP and saved into LDAP. READ_ONLY is Read-only LDAP mode where role mappings are retrieved from both LDAP and DB and merged together. New role grants are not saved to LDAP but to DB. IMPORT is Read-only LDAP mode where role mappings are retrieved from LDAP just at the time when user is imported from LDAP and then they are saved to local keycloak DB.

properties.name: user.roles.retrieve.strategy
properties.label: User Roles Retrieve Strategy
properties.helpText: Specify how to retrieve roles of user. LOAD_ROLES_BY_MEMBER_ATTRIBUTE means that roles of user will be retrieved by sending LDAP query to retrieve all roles where 'member' is our user. GET_ROLES_FROM_USER_MEMBEROF_ATTRIBUTE means that roles of user will be retrieved from 'memberOf' attribute of our user. Or from the other attribute specified by 'Member-Of LDAP Attribute' .

properties.name: memberof.ldap.attribute
properties.label: Member-Of LDAP Attribute
properties.helpText: Used just when 'User Roles Retrieve Strategy' is GET_ROLES_FROM_USER_MEMBEROF_ATTRIBUTE . It specifies the name of the LDAP attribute on the LDAP user, which contains the roles (LDAP Groups), which the user is member of. Usually it will be 'memberOf' and that's also the default value.

properties.name: use.realm.roles.mapping
properties.label: Use Realm Roles Mapping
properties.helpText: If true, then LDAP role mappings will be mapped to realm role mappings in Keycloak. Otherwise it will be mapped to client role mappings

properties.name: client.id
properties.label: Client ID
properties.helpText: Client ID of client to which LDAP role mappings will be mapped. Applicable just if 'Use Realm Roles Mapping' is false

org.keycloak.storage.ldap.mappers.LDAPSt.helpText: Used to map single attribute from LDAP user to attribute of UserModel in Keycloak DB

properties.name: user.model.attribute
properties.label: User Model Attribute
properties.helpText: Name of the UserModel property or attribute you want to map the LDAP attribute into. For example 'firstName', 'lastName, 'email', 'street' etc.

properties.name: ldap.attribute
properties.label: LDAP Attribute
properties.helpText: Name of mapped attribute on LDAP object. For example 'cn', 'sn, 'mail', 'street' etc.

properties.name: read.only
properties.label: Read Only
properties.helpText: Read-only attribute is imported from LDAP to UserModel, but it's not saved back to LDAP when user is updated in Keycloak.

properties.name: Script
properties.label: Script
properties.helpText:
Script to compute the attribute value. 
 Available variables: 
 'user' - the current user.
 'realm' - the current realm.
 'clientSession' - the current clientSession.
 'userSession' - the current userSession.
 'keycloakSession' - the current keycloakSession.

To use: the last statement is the value returned to Java.
The result will be tested if it can be iterated upon (e.g. an array or a collection).
 - If it is not, toString() will be called on the object to get the value of the attribute
 - If it is, toString() will be called on all elements to return multiple attribute values.
properties.defaultValue:
/**
 * Available variables: 
 * user - the current user
 * realm - the current realm
 * clientSession - the current clientSession
 * userSession - the current userSession
 * keycloakSession - the current keycloakSession
 */


//insert your code here...

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.condi.helpText: The condition is satisfied by any client on any event.

properties.name: is-negative-logic
properties.label: Negative Logic
properties.helpText: If On, the result of condition's evaluation is reverted from true to false and vice versa.

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.condi.helpText: It uses the client's access type (confidential, public, bearer-only) to determine whether the policy is applied. Condition is checked during most of OpenID Connect requests (Authorization request, token requests, introspection endpoint request etc).

properties.name: is-negative-logic
properties.label: Negative Logic
properties.helpText: If On, the result of condition's evaluation is reverted from true to false and vice versa.

properties.name: type
properties.label: client-accesstype.label
properties.helpText: client-accesstype.tooltip

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.condi.helpText: The condition checks whether one of the specified client roles exists on the client to determine whether the policy is applied. This effectively allows client administrator to create client role of specified name on the client to make sure that particular client policy will be applied on requests of this client. Condition is checked during most of OpenID Connect requests (Authorization request, token requests, introspection endpoint request etc).

properties.name: is-negative-logic
properties.label: Negative Logic
properties.helpText: If On, the result of condition's evaluation is reverted from true to false and vice versa.

properties.name: roles
properties.label: client-roles.label
properties.helpText: client-roles-condition.tooltip

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.condi.helpText: It uses the scopes requested or assigned in advance to the client to determine whether the policy is applied to this client. Condition is evaluated during OpenID Connect authorization request and/or token request.

properties.name: is-negative-logic
properties.label: Negative Logic
properties.helpText: If On, the result of condition's evaluation is reverted from true to false and vice versa.

properties.name: scopes
properties.label: client-scopes-condition.label
properties.helpText: client-scopes-condition.tooltip

properties.name: type
properties.label: Scope Type
properties.helpText: If set to 'Default', condition evaluates to true if client has some default scopes of the values specified by the 'Expected Scopes' property. If set to 'Optional', condition evaluates to true if client has some optional scopes of the values specified by the 'Expected Scopes' property and at the same time, the scope were used as a value of 'scope' parameter in the request

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.condi.helpText: The condition checks the context how is client created/updated to determine whether the policy is applied. For example it checks if client is created with admin REST API or OIDC dynamic client registration. And for the letter case if it is ANONYMOUS client registration or AUTHENTICATED client registration with Initial access token or Registration access token and so on.

properties.name: is-negative-logic
properties.label: Negative Logic
properties.helpText: If On, the result of condition's evaluation is reverted from true to false and vice versa.

properties.name: update-client-source
properties.label: Update Client Context
properties.helpText: Specifies the context how is client created or updated. ByInitialAccessToken is usually OpenID Connect client registration with the initial access token. ByRegistrationAccessToken is usually OpenID Connect client update request with the registration access token. ByAuthenticatedUser is usually Admin REST request with the token on behalf of authenticated user or client (service account). ByAnonymous is usually anonymous OpenID Client registration request.

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.condi.helpText: The condition checks the group of the entity who tries to create/update the client to determine whether the policy is applied.

properties.name: is-negative-logic
properties.label: Negative Logic
properties.helpText: If On, the result of condition's evaluation is reverted from true to false and vice versa.

properties.name: groups
properties.label: client-updater-source-groups.label
properties.helpText: client-updater-source-groups.tooltip

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.condi.helpText: The condition checks the host/domain of the entity who tries to create/update the client to determine whether the policy is applied.

properties.name: is-negative-logic
properties.label: Negative Logic
properties.helpText: If On, the result of condition's evaluation is reverted from true to false and vice versa.

properties.name: trusted-hosts
properties.label: client-updater-trusted-hosts.label
properties.helpText: client-updater-trusted-hosts.tooltip

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.condi.helpText: The condition checks the role of the entity who tries to create/update the client to determine whether the policy is applied.

properties.name: is-negative-logic
properties.label: Negative Logic
properties.helpText: If On, the result of condition's evaluation is reverted from true to false and vice versa.

properties.name: roles
properties.label: client-updater-source-roles.label
properties.helpText: client-updater-source-roles.tooltip

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: On authorization endpoint and token endpoint, this executor checks whether the client is confidential client. If not, it denies its request.
When present, then registered/updated clients will be verified to have 'consentRequired' switch enabled and eventually will be auto-configured for 'consentRequired' switch to be enabled

properties.name: auto-configure
properties.label: Auto-configure
properties.helpText: If On, the configuration of the client will be auto-configured to enable consentRequired during client creation or update.If Off, the clients are validated to have consentRequired enabled during create/update client

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: When present, then registered/updated clients will be verified to have 'fullScopeAllowed' switch disabled and eventually will be auto-configured for 'fullScopeAllowed' switch to be disabled

properties.name: auto-configure
properties.label: Auto-configure
properties.helpText: If On, the configuration of the client will be auto-configured to disable fullScopeAllowed during client creation or update.If off, the clients are validated to not have fullScopeAllowed enabled during create/update client

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: It prohibits the client whose MTLS certificate does not match with the certificate thumbprint from the tokens.

properties.name: auto-configure
properties.label: Auto-configure
properties.helpText: If On, then the during client creation or update, the configuration of the client will be auto-configured to use MTLS HoK token

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: It makes the client enforce Proof Key for Code Exchange operation with secure algorithm like S256.

properties.name: auto-configure
properties.label: Auto-configure
properties.helpText: If On, then the during client creation or update, the configuration of the client will be auto-configured to enforce usage of PKCE with secure algorithm S256

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: It makes keycloak to reject a resource owner password credentials grant.

properties.name: auto-configure
properties.label: Auto-configure
properties.helpText: If On, then the during client creation or update, the configuration of the client will be auto-configured to reject a resource owner password credentials grant.

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: It refuses the client whose signature algorithms are considered not to be secure. This is applied by server for CIBA backchannel signed authentication request. It accepts ES256, ES384, ES512, PS256, PS384 and PS512.

properties.name: default-algorithm
properties.label: Default Algorithm
properties.helpText: Default signature algorithm, which will be set to clients during client registration/update in case that client does not specify any algorithm

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: To distinguish which authentication belongs to which CIBA flow, it refuses backchannel authentication request which lacks 'binding_message' parameter.
The executor checks whether the client treats the signed authentication request in its CIBA backchannel authentication request by following Financial-grade API CIBA Security Profile.

properties.name: available-period
properties.label: Available Period
properties.helpText: The maximum period in seconds for which the 'request' signed authentication request used in CIBA backchannel authentication request is considered valid.

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: It makes the client enforce registering/updating secure client authentication.

properties.name: allowed-client-authenticators
properties.label: Allowed Client Authenticators
properties.helpText: List of available client authentication methods, which are allowed for clients to use. Other client authentication methods will not be allowed.

properties.name: default-client-authenticator
properties.label: Default Client Authenticator
properties.helpText: This client authentication method will be set as the authentication method to new clients during register/update request of the client in case that client does not have explicitly set other client authenticator method. If it is not set, then the client authenticator won't be set on new clients. Regardless the value of this option, client is still always validated to match with any of the allowed client authentication methods

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: It prohibits the client registering/specifying http scheme URI.
Enforces certain constraints on how clients should support logout.

properties.name: allow-front-channel-logout
properties.label: Allow Front-Channel Logout
properties.helpText: If On, then front-channel logout should be allowed. Otherwise, clients should favor other logout mechanisms such as back-channel logout.

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: The executor checks whether the client treats the request object in its authorization request by following Financial-grade API Security Profile : Read and Write API Security Profile.

properties.name: verify-nbf
properties.label: Verify Not-Before
properties.helpText: If ON, then it will be verified if 'request' object used in OIDC authorization request contains not-before claim and this claim will be validated

properties.name: available-period
properties.label: Available Period
properties.helpText: The maximum period in seconds for which the 'request' object used in OIDC authorization request is considered valid. It is used if 'Verify Not-Before' is ON.

properties.name: encryption-required
properties.label: Encryption Required
properties.helpText: Whether request object encryption is required. If enabled, request objects must be encrypted. Otherwise, encryption is optional.

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: The executor checks whether the client sent its authorization request with code id_token or code id_token token in its response type depending on its setting.

properties.name: auto-configure
properties.label: Auto-configure
properties.helpText: If On, then the during client creation or update, the configuration of the client will be auto-configured to use ID token returned from authorization endpoint as detached signature.

properties.name: allow-token-response-type
properties.label: Allow-token-response-type
properties.helpText: If On, then it allows an access token returned from authorization endpoint in hybrid flow.

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: To prevent CSRF, it refuses the client's authorization request which lacks 'nonce' parameter in OIDC flow or 'state' parameter in OAuth2 grant.

It refuses the client whose signature algorithms are considered not to be secure. This is applied by server for signing ID Token, UserInfo and Access Token. Also it is used by client for Token Endpoint Authentication signature algorithm (for JWT client authenticators) and OIDC Request object. It accepts ES256, ES384, ES512, PS256, PS384 and PS512.

properties.name: default-algorithm
properties.label: Default Algorithm
properties.helpText: Default signature algorithm, which will be set to clients during client registration/update in case that client does not specify any algorithm

org.keycloak.services.clientpolicy.execu.helpText: It refuses the client whose JWT token signature algorithms are considered not to be secure. It accepts ES256, ES384, ES512, PS256, PS384 and PS512.

properties.name: require-client-assertion
properties.label: Require Client Assertion
properties.helpText: If this is ON, then parameter 'client_assertion' will be required in the requests and request will fail if it is not present. If false, then parameter 'client_assertion' is not required in the requests, which is convenient for example for clients authenticating with MTLS. When 'client_assertion' parameter is present in the request, then the algorithm on the JWT from specified client assertion is always checked regardless of the value of this switch

org.keycloak.broker.provider.IdentityPro.helpText: Import user profile information if it exists in Social provider JSON data into the specified user attribute.

properties.name: jsonField
properties.label: Social Profile JSON Field Path
properties.helpText: Path of field in Social provider User Profile JSON data to get value from. You can use dot notation for nesting and square brackets for array index. Eg. 'contact.address[0].country'.

properties.name: userAttribute
properties.label: User Attribute Name
properties.helpText: User attribute name to store information into.

org.keycloak.broker.provider.IdentityPro.helpText: Looks for an external role in a keycloak access token.  If external role exists, grant the user the specified realm or client role.

properties.name: external.role
properties.label: External role
properties.helpText: External role to check for.  To reference a client role the syntax is clientname.clientrole, i.e. myclient.myrole

properties.name: role
properties.label: Role
properties.helpText: Role to grant to user if external role is present.  Click 'Select Role' button to browse roles, or just type it in the textbox.  To reference a client role the syntax is clientname.clientrole, i.e. myclient.myrole

org.keycloak.broker.provider.IdentityPro.helpText: If all claims exists, assign the user to the specified group.

properties.name: claims
properties.label: Claims
properties.helpText: Name and value of the claims to search for in token. You can reference nested claims using a '.', i.e. 'address.locality'. To use dot (.) literally, escape it with backslash (\.)

properties.name: are.claim.values.regex
properties.label: Regex Claim Values
properties.helpText: If enabled claim values are interpreted as regular expressions.

properties.name: group
properties.label: Group
properties.helpText: Group to assign the user to if claim is present.

org.keycloak.broker.provider.IdentityPro.helpText: If all claims exists, grant the user the specified realm or client role.

properties.name: claims
properties.label: Claims
properties.helpText: Name and value of the claims to search for in token. You can reference nested claims using a '.', i.e. 'address.locality'. To use dot (.) literally, escape it with backslash (\.)

properties.name: are.claim.values.regex
properties.label: Regex Claim Values
properties.helpText: If enabled claim values are interpreted as regular expressions.

properties.name: role
properties.label: Role
properties.helpText: Role to grant to user if claim is present. Click 'Select Role' button to browse roles, or just type it in the textbox. To reference a client role the syntax is clientname.clientrole, i.e. myclient.myrole

org.keycloak.broker.provider.IdentityPro.helpText: When user is imported from provider, hardcode a role mapping for it.

properties.name: role
properties.label: Role
properties.helpText: Role to grant to user.  Click 'Select Role' button to browse roles, or just type it in the textbox.  To reference a client role the syntax is clientname.clientrole, i.e. myclient.myrole

org.keycloak.broker.provider.IdentityPro.helpText: If a claim exists, grant the user the specified realm or client role.

properties.name: claim
properties.label: Claim
properties.helpText: Name of claim to search for in token. You can reference nested claims using a '.', i.e. 'address.locality'. To use dot (.) literally, escape it with backslash (\.)

properties.name: claim.value
properties.label: Claim Value
properties.helpText: Value the claim must have.  If the claim is an array, then the value must be contained in the array.

properties.name: role
properties.label: Role
properties.helpText: Role to grant to user if claim is present.  Click 'Select Role' button to browse roles, or just type it in the textbox.  To reference a client role the syntax is clientname.clientrole, i.e. myclient.myrole

org.keycloak.broker.provider.IdentityPro.helpText: Import declared claim if it exists in ID, access token or the claim set returned by the user profile endpoint into the specified user property or attribute.

properties.name: claim
properties.label: Claim
properties.helpText: Name of claim to search for in token. You can reference nested claims using a '.', i.e. 'address.locality'. To use dot (.) literally, escape it with backslash (\.)

properties.name: user.attribute
properties.label: User Attribute Name
properties.helpText: User attribute name to store claim.  Use email, lastName, and firstName to map to those predefined user properties.

org.keycloak.broker.provider.IdentityPro.helpText: Format the username to import.

properties.name: template
properties.label: Template
properties.helpText:
Template to use to format the username to import.  Substitutions are enclosed in ${}.  For example: '${ALIAS}.${CLAIM.sub}'.  ALIAS is the provider alias.  CLAIM.<NAME> references an ID or Access token claim. 
The substitution can be converted to upper or lower case by appending |uppercase or |lowercase to the substituted value, e.g. '${CLAIM.sub | lowercase}

properties.name: target
properties.label: Target
properties.helpText: Destination field for the mapper. LOCAL (default) means that the changes are applied to the username stored in local database upon user import. BROKER_ID and BROKER_USERNAME means that the changes are stored into the ID or username used for federation user lookup, respectively.

org.keycloak.broker.provider.IdentityPro.helpText: Import user profile information if it exists in Social provider JSON data into the specified user attribute.

properties.name: jsonField
properties.label: Social Profile JSON Field Path
properties.helpText: Path of field in Social provider User Profile JSON data to get value from. You can use dot notation for nesting and square brackets for array index. Eg. 'contact.address[0].country'.

properties.name: userAttribute
properties.label: User Attribute Name
properties.helpText: User attribute name to store information into.

org.keycloak.broker.provider.IdentityPro.helpText: Import user profile information if it exists in Social provider JSON data into the specified user attribute.

properties.name: userAttribute
properties.label: User Attribute Name
properties.helpText: User attribute name to store information into.

org.keycloak.broker.provider.IdentityPro.helpText: If the set of attributes exists and can be matched, grant the user the specified realm or client role.

properties.name: attributes
properties.label: Attributes
properties.helpText: Name and (regex) value of the attributes to search for in token.  The configured name of an attribute is searched in SAML attribute name and attribute friendly name fields. Every given attribute description must be met to set the role. If the attribute is an array, then the value must be contained in the array. If an attribute can be found several times, then one match is sufficient.

properties.name: are.attribute.values.regex
properties.label: Regex Attribute Values
properties.helpText: If enabled attribute values are interpreted as regular expressions.

properties.name: role
properties.label: Role
properties.helpText: Role to grant to user if all attributes are present. Click 'Select Role' button to browse roles, or just type it in the textbox. To reference a client role the syntax is clientname.clientrole, i.e. myclient.myrole

org.keycloak.broker.provider.IdentityPro.helpText: If an attribute exists, grant the user the specified realm or client role.

properties.name: attribute.name
properties.label: Attribute Name
properties.helpText: Name of attribute to search for in assertion.  You can leave this blank and specify a friendly name instead.

properties.name: attribute.friendly.name
properties.label: Friendly Name
properties.helpText: Friendly name of attribute to search for in assertion.  You can leave this blank and specify a name instead.

properties.name: attribute.value
properties.label: Attribute Value
properties.helpText: Value the attribute must have.  If the attribute is a list, then the value must be contained in the list.

properties.name: role

properties.helpText: Role to grant to user.  Click 'Select Role' button to browse roles, or just type it in the textbox.  To reference a client role the syntax is clientname.clientrole, i.e. myclient.myrole
